III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157 Health services; policies and
Section procedures.
Description (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures that address all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was also found to have a fractured finger.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed via phone on 8/1/23 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. He reported believing he hurt his left index
finger 2 months ago while playing catch with a football at the
detention facility. He believed the injury to only be a jammed finger
and he didn’t ask for an examination because he didn’t think the
finger was broken. He reported being given a “big white pill” to
help reduce the pain in his finger. Once lodged at his new
placement, his hand was x-rayed, and it was discovered his left
index finger had been broken. He also reported having a belief
that his big right toe was broken and staff “didn’t do shit about it”.
He reported telling Nurse 1 and Nurse 2, about his foot. Youth A
reported having seizures because he “pushes my body to hard”
and will collapse. He believes his new placement cares more
about providing care for him than the detention facility did.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were interviewed face to
face at the facility on 8/1/23. They reported youth are allowed to
play catch with a football in an outside courtyard.
Administrator 3 and Administrator 4 were interviewed face to
face at the facility on 8/3/23 in collaboration with MDHHS
2

worker. In regard to Youth A’s broken finger, they reported the
only documented treatment for his finger occurred on 7/25/23
when he complained of pain of his index finger and nursing found
his cuticle to be red and swollen. Because Youth A has a history
of biting his nails, it was believed his cuticle was infected and an
ointment was provided. Because of the information provided by
Youth A, there was no suspicion of a fracture.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/3/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported the
medical department was very attentive to him since he often had
some form of medical complaint. She didn’t recall any complaints
about a finger or toe from Youth A.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/3/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. There was never a
report about a finger or toe injury.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 8/25/23. She
reported having nothing new to add to what was reported in the
allegations.
Nurse 2 was interviewed via phone on 8/25/23 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. She did not recall Youth A reporting he
broke his toe. She reported the process for youth reporting some
type of injury is filling out “Health Service request” which is kept in
their files for documentation. She described Youth A always had
something medical going on and he was very good at getting
attention and manipulating others.
Email dated 8/3/23 from Administrator 3. The email documents,
Youth A submitted a health care request form on 6/22/23 reporting
pain in his left index finger. The detention medical staff evaluated
him, and treatment was provided. He again submitted a health
care request form on 7/25/23 and his left index finger was found to
be swollen and red, along with painful when bent. A medical
provider was consulted, and Youth A was given an antibiotic.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation, evidence
supports that medical staff at the detention center provided
medical care in an appropriate manner to all the medical needs
including the “broken finger” Youth A presented while in care.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157 Health services; policies and
Section procedures. (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health
Description service policies and procedures that address all of the following:
3

(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was admitted to the new facility without the requested 30-
day supply of medication and when provided medication, it was
the wrong dose.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed via phone on 8/1/23 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. He reported receiving seizure medication
(one large white pill) twice a day at the detention facility but at
times would stop taking the medication because he “felt weird”. He
believed the dose was “900 something” in the morning and “1500
something” in the evening. Once he had a seizure while playing
basketball and woke up in the hospital which resulted in the
seizure medication. While in the detention facility, when he
experienced a seizure, staff would call for medical support. He
reported being transported to the new facility by the County
Sheriff’s department. He never reported receiving the wrong
medication.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were interviewed face to
face at the facility on 8/1/23. They reported Youth A has a
history of seizures and there is a questions if the seizures are real
or not. Youth A was in the hospital for a week in an effort to
determine if the seizures were real or “something else”. They also
reported Youth A left the facility for his new placement on 7/28/23.
They never reported Youth A received the wrong dose of
medication. They sent the medication on hand with instructions in
the discharge summary of the dose for Youth A.
Administrator 3 and Administrator 4 were interviewed face to
face at the facility on 8/3/23 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. They reported when a youth is leaving, they will provide a
supply of medication that they have on file, and this is outlined in
the youth’s discharge summary. They described the process that
took place with Youth A being discharged. Probation Officer
emailed the facility on 7/19/23 notifying them Youth A will be
replaced to another facility in a “few weeks”. All of the discharge
information is sent to the Probation Officer to pass along to the
next possible placement so they can evaluation information prior
to accepting a youth. On 7/28/23 the Sheriff’s department
transporter showed up unannounced at the facility to transport
Youth A to his new placement. Nurse 2 was notified by the new
placement, that they had not received a 30-day supply of
medication for Youth A. Nurse 2 contacted Clinician 1 who gave
permission for a new prescription which Nurse 2 called into the
requested pharmacy (Walgreens in Grayling). A couple of hours
4

later Administrator 1 notified Administrator 3 the new placement
had filed a licensing complaint about not receiving a 30-day supply
of medication and not receiving the correct dose of medication
from the pharmacy for Youth A. Administrator 2 called the
pharmacy asking why they had not filled the prescription as
ordered. The order was for a supply of 1-300 mg and 2-600 mg
seizure medication daily to which they provided 3- 300 mg daily.
When Youth A was in the hospital, he received a higher dose of
medication which was changed by the treating physician after
Youth A was found to be within therapeutic limits with a lower
dose. After the change, the medication stayed at the 1 tab 300 mg
in the morning and 2 tabs 600 in the evening.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/3/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being
familiar with Youth A and described him as “very manipulative”
and unwilling to take responsibility for his own actions. She also
reported liking Youth A and understanding that he had many
medical concerns.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/3/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported no
knowledge of what medication or dose of medication was provided
at discharge for Youth A.
Administrator 3 was interviewed via phone on 8/25/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported Youth A’s
seizure medication regiment as Trileptal – Oxcarbazepine with the
dose being one 300 mg tab in the morning and two 600 mg tabs at
bedtime. She also reported Nurse 2 called the pharmacy in
Grayling (Shawono) to ensure the medication was made available
to the new placement. She believed the new placement called in a
prescription for three 300 mg tabs of Trileptal rather than the
correct dose of one 300 tab and two 600 mg tabs, but she is
unsure where the mistake took place. She reported when
receiving the notice (7/18/23) from Probation Officer of Youth A’s
planned replacement within the next few weeks, they sent
(7/19/23) the medical information along with other information
(Discharge summary) to Probation Officer. Youth A was replaced
on 7/28/23 when the Sheriff’s Office transporter showed up
unannounced at the facility. This didn’t give the facility 5 to 7 days’
notice which they need to prepare all medication for the transfer.
Administrator 3 reported they can only order more medication
after the on-site supply reaches 5-7 days left and on 7/28/23 they
had just reached a 7-day left of the Trileptal. Administrator 3
reported they sent the 7-day supply. Administrator 3 reported
5

informing the probation department they need to notify the facility
the actual date of transfer with plenty of lead time so medication
can be secured and if not they can send only what they have on
hand. She also reported a refill of the Trileptal was ordered on
7/16/23 but because of the rules for medication, the pharmacy will
not fill the prescription until there are only 7-days’ supply left at the
facility. There is stock supplies of medication at the facility but that
is to be used for youth at the facility waiting their prescription
refills. She also reported the dose of Trileptal was changed by the
attending physician in February 2023.
Probation Officer was interviewed via phone on 8/25/23. She
reported informing the facility of Youth A transferring to the new
placement on 7/18/23. She was waiting for an opening at the new
placement but informed he was accepted. She received the
packet from the facility on 7/19/23 and forward this information to
the new placement the next day. She also reported not being
aware of the situation with the medication until receiving a phone
call from the new placement three days after Youth A arrived. She
believed the situation with the medication was resolved after she
contacted the clinic at Youth A’s former placement.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 8/25/23. She
reported Youth A entered their care without enough medication
and the medication they received from the pharmacy was the
wrong dose. She reported contacting Probation Officer who put
her in contact with the nurse at the former facility so they could get
the medication.
Physician 1 was interviewed via phone on 8/29/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported taking care of
Youth A while he was lodged in the detention facility. He denied
knowing about any medication issues as outlined in the
allegations. He also reported treating Youth A for anxiety and
ADHD. The treatment for anxiety was in regard to the pseudo
seizures Youth A was experiencing. He reported approving an
additional prescription of the seizure medication (Trileptal) to be
called to Walgreens in Gaylord.
JJ Worker was interviewed via phone on 9/1/23. She reported
a belief that the detention facility provided no medication for Youth
A. She also reported having no new information to provide.
Documents Reviewed:
6

Medication list for Youth A without a date authored by the
detention facility. Oxcarbazepine 600 mg 2-tab daily is listed with
a start date of 7/25/23 and an end date of 8/23/23. The clinician is
identified as Clinician 1. Oxcarbazepine 300 mg 1 tab daily by
mouth is also listed with a start date of 7/13/23 and an end date of
8/10/23. The clinician is identified as Clinician 1.
Medical & Behavioral Health Admission Care Screen for
Youth A dated 9/12/22 by Administrator 3. This document
outlines medical and behavioral health issues, or none as issues
that Youth A presented at time of placement at Kent County
Juvenile Detention Center (KCJDC). It is noted Youth A has a
history of non-epileptic seizures and there was no medication
brought into the facility with him. A summary of “problems” was
outlined. These include the following. Attention-deficit hyperactivity
disorder, combined type F443.12, post-traumatic stress disorder
chronic G40.89 and other seizures. It is also documented Youth A
received a referral for Psychiatric consultation on a routine basis.
Psychiatric Provider Follow-up BH 12.1 without a date. This
document states, Youth A in no way acts psychotic but remains
generally problematic. Youth A’s Seroquel is to be increased to
200 mg.
Email correspondence from Probation Officer covering
7/20/23 to 7/28/23. On 7/20/23 Probation Officer sent the intake
information to Shawono. On 7/20/23 Shawono responded and
asked if transportation was available next week. 7/21/23 Probation
Officer responded that Friday next week will work. 7/24/23
Shawono responded by asking for a phone call on Friday to
provide an ETA. 7/28/23 JJ Worker requesting information on
Youth A’s statues. 7/28/23 Shawono responds Youth A has
arrived and they are working on obtaining enough medication for
him. 7/28/23 JJ Worker questions if he didn’t arrive with 30-day
supply of medication or a prescription. 7/28/23 Shawono responds
that Youth A did not arrive with 30-day supply of medication nor
prescription. They also report their nurse is working on resolving
this issue. 7/28/23 Shawono writes to Probation Officer that Youth
A is at Shawono and has only a few days of medication left. Their
psychiatrist is on vacation and unable to prescribe medications at
this time. 7/28/23 Probation Officer writes back indicating
Shawono can call the detention clinic after 2:30 to enquire about
medication.
Munson Healthcare Grayling Hospital 7/30/2023 for Youth A.
This document outlines the diagnosis from Youth A’s “seizure,
7

Medication management, and Fracture of phalanx of left index
finger”. Youth A is to take 900 mg of oxcarbazepine in the morning
and 1200 mg of oxcarbazepine at night. Youth A is also to follow
up with an Orthopedic Surgeon as soon as possible.
Email stream from Probation Officer to Administrator 3 dated
7/19/23 for Youth A. Probation Officer informed Administrator 3
on 7/19/23 Youth A will be placed within a few weeks, and she did
not want Youth A informed of this information. She also attached a
form that outlines the information she will need for the transfer, but
the form is missing from the emails. The detention facility
responded on 7/19/23 with an attached list of medications and
psychological assessments for Youth A. The attachment sent
back to Probation Officer included a Medication list (reviewed
above), Medical & Behavioral Health Admission Care Screen
(reviewed above), and Psychiatric Provider follow-up (reviewed
above).
Text message screen shot dated Friday July 28, 2023.
Clinician 1 responds to a request from the detention facility to call
in a prescription at Walgreens for more medication because Youth
A’s new placement is not comfortable with the number of
medications available. Clinician 1 responds that the detention
facility may call them in for 30-days.
VitalCore Health Strategies form #201 Personal medication
log for Youth A dated 7/28/23. This document outlines the
number of pills for each medication Youth A was released from
the detention facility when transferred to his new placement. The
following is a list of the medication, number of pills and dose
provided at time of discharge.
• Vyvanse (Lisdexamfetamine Di mesylate) 60 mg 9 pills
1Xdaily
• Sulfamethoxazole 800-160 mg 10 pills 2Xdaily
• Oxcarbazepine 300 mg 7 pills 1Xdaily
• Zoloft 50 mg 99 pills 3Xdaily
• Noprilam 5 mg for finger
Discharge Planning DP-1.0 for Youth A dated 7/28/23. This
document outlines issues involving Youth A at time of discharge.
His diagnoses are listed and involve Attention-deficit hyperactivity
disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, other seizures, and
cutaneous mycobacterial infection for his right antecubital. His
medications are listed including the milligram number of tabs and
dose. His seizure medication dose is listed as Oxcarbazepine 600
8

mg 2 tabs daily (evening) and 300 mg 1 tab daily (morning). This
plan is documented as being addressed with Youth A.
Full patient history for Youth A without a date. The release
forms are present and again list the medication he is taking or is
prescribed for him (noting he has refused to take medication at
times). Youth A had numerous exams through his stay in the
detention facility. Youth A began his regiment of anti-seizure
medication 300 mg 1 tab daily in the morning and 600 mg 2 tab
daily in the evening on with his first order for the 600 mg occurring
on 9/11/22 and the first order for the 300 mg occurring on 9/12/23.
The last order for the 600 mg occurred on 7/16/23 and the last
order for the 300 mg occurred on 7/11/23. Throughout the time
period between the first and last, there were no gaps in orders for
this medication and the level of medication did not change.
Email dated 8/3/23 from Administrator 3 addressing the
replacement of Youth A and his medication. In summary this
email outlines the history of Youth A’s seizures and the detention
facility’s treatment and evaluations of these seizures. Youth A had
several evaluations including two neurological evaluations to
determine the type of seizures he was experiencing. Youth A was
being evaluated every three months and provided with a regiment
of medication. All medication for Youth A currently on site were
sent along with a discharge summary outlining Youth A’s doses
and directions for his medication with the Sheriff’s department
transporter. Nursing staff was then notified by the new placement
that they had not received a 30-day supply of medications.
Nursing staff contacted their provider for orders to call in a
prescription for more medication to the pharmacy identified by the
new placement. The new prescription would have supplied a 30-
day amount of medication for Youth A.
Health Services Policy and Procedure – Discharge Planning #
E-13.00 dated 9/30/22. This document was provided by the
detention program and is used to guide the medical part of a youth
being discharged. Compliance indicators include for planned
discharges medical staff are to arrange for a reasonable supply of
current medications. It is also stated that if the youth is being
replaced to a “jail” setting then a fourteen-day supply of
medication of non-narcotic medication unless the prescription
expires earlier. In this case the release was unplanned, and the
prescription was expiring causing there to be limited medication
(see medical log for medication available at time of unplanned
replacement).
9

Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation, evidence
supports that medical staff provided the appropriate medication for
the transfer of Youth A even though they did not provide the
requested 30-day supply at time of transfer, they were able to
have the medication available (once notified) at the local
pharmacy. There appears to be a communication issue since both
facilities were communicating through Youth A’s probation officer
rather than direct communication.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that this investigation be closed with no change made to the
license of this Court Operated Facility.
